summary: An internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the annual process for requesting forfeiture funding from the Department of Justice. It provides guidance to unit chiefs on submitting funding requests for FY22, specifically mentioning the Epstein/Maxwell case as an example of a case with related expenses.

persons.name: Andrew
persons.role: Co-compiler of funding requests, likely an AUSA or coordinator
persons.context: Mentioned as working with the email's author to compile the office's forfeiture funding requests for FY22. AUSAs are instructed to email completed request forms to him and the author.

events.title: Deadline for unit funding requests
events.description: Unit chiefs are instructed to gather and submit their forfeiture funding requests for FY22 by this date.

events.title: Deadline for office funding request to EOUSA
events.description: The compiled office-wide forfeiture funding requests for FY22 are due to the Executive Office for United States Attorneys (EOUSA).

events.title: FY22 Funding Period
events.description: The period for which the requested forfeiture funds are intended to cover expenses (October 1, 2021 to September 30, 2022).

keyFacts: The document is an internal SDNY email outlining the process for requesting federal forfeiture funds to cover large case expenses for the upcoming fiscal year (FY22).

It references the 'Epstein/Maxwell' case explicitly in an attached document title ('_Large_Case_Related_Expenses_-_Epstem_Maxwell.docx'), indicating it was an active case with anticipated significant expenses requiring special funding.

Guidance specifies that funding requests should only be made for cases where the estimated amount of forfeitable assets exceeds $1 million, justifying the expense as an investment to secure a larger forfeiture.

Allowable expenses include payments to outside vendors for financial analysis, document review, forensic analysis, expert consultants, data hosting (specifically mentioning Relativity on PAE Labat), translation, and foreign travel.
The email demonstrates the procedural and financial mechanisms within the DOJ for supporting complex, high-value prosecutions like the Epstein/Maxwell case.
